subject: linear_algebra
title: Span and Linear Combinations
contentHtml:
A spanning set is a set of vectors that can be used to generate all possible linear combinations.

Geometrically, it's like having a set of arrows that, when combined in different ways, can reach every point in space.

intuition: The key insight is that a spanning set gives us the smallest subspace containing all its elements.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Spanning Sets and Linear Combinations
contentHtml:
A set of vectors is said to span a vector space if every vector in that space can be expressed as a linear combination of the vectors in the set.

Geometrically, this means that any point in the space can be reached by moving along the directions defined by the spanning set.
name: Span of a set" },
intuition: Think of the spanning set as a 'coordinate system' for the vector space. Any point in the space can be reached by combining the directions defined by the vectors in the set.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, we often work with feature spaces that are spanned by a set of basis vectors (e.g., principal components).
commonMistakes: Don't confuse spanning sets with bases. A spanning set can contain redundant or linearly dependent vectors.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Span and Linear Combinations
contentHtml:
A set of vectors is said to span a vector space if every vector in that space can be expressed as a linear combination of the vectors in the set.

This means that the span of a set of vectors is the smallest subspace containing all the vectors in the set. Geometrically, this corresponds to the subspace generated by the vectors when they are plotted in n-dimensional space.
name: Span Formula" },
intuition: The concept of span is crucial in linear algebra as it allows us to identify the smallest subspace containing a set of vectors. This has significant implications for applications such as machine learning, where we often work with high-dimensional spaces and need to find the most relevant features.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, finding the span of a set of features can help in dimensionality reduction, feature selection, and model interpretation.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse the span of a set of vectors with the subspace generated by the vectors; they are not always equal.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Span of a Set of Vectors
contentHtml:
The span of a set of vectors is the smallest subspace containing all linear combinations of those vectors.

This concept is crucial in many areas of mathematics and computer science, including machine learning and artificial intelligence.

formula.latex: \[\text{span}(S) = \left\{ c_1 v_1 + \cdots + c_k v_k | c_i \in F \right\}\]
formula.name: Span of a Set

intuition: Think of the span as the 'shadow' or 'image' of the original set of vectors. It's the smallest subspace that contains all possible linear combinations of those vectors.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, the span is used to represent the decision boundary of a classifier.

and

solutionHtml:
To find the span, we first generate some linear combinations:

\(\mathbf{w}_1 = 2\mathbf{v}_1 + \mathbf{v}_2 = \begin{bmatrix} 6 \\ 7 \\ 9 \end{bmatrix}\)

\(\mathbf{w}_2 = -3\mathbf{v}_1 + 2\mathbf{v}_2 = \begin{bmatrix} -3 \\ -4 \\ -5 \end{bmatrix}\)

The span is the set of all such linear combinations. Can you see why these two vectors are enough to generate any other vector in this span?

statementHtml: Find the span of the set \{v_1 = (1, 0), v_2 = (0, 1)\} in R^2.",
hints: Think about what vectors can be written as linear combinations of these two.
Consider the geometric interpretation: which directions are spanned by these vectors?
Use the definition of span to find the smallest subspace containing these vectors.
solutionHtml:
To find the span, we need to determine all possible linear combinations of v_1 and v_2. We can write any vector in the form c_1v_1 + c_2v_2 = (c_1, c_2), where c_1, c_2 \in R.

The span contains all vectors that can be written as linear combinations of these two. This includes all possible directions and points in the plane.

",
answerShort: The span is the entire plane R^2." },

subject: linear_algebra
statementHtml: Find the span of the set S = {(1, 0), (0, 1)} in ℝ².
hints: Think about what vectors can be written as linear combinations of these two vectors.
Consider the geometric interpretation: which directions are possible?
Use the definition of span to narrow down your answer.
solutionHtml:
To find the span, we need to determine the set of all linear combinations of S.

Let's start with a general vector (x, y) in ℝ². We can write it as:

\[ (x, y) = c_1(1, 0) + c_2(0, 1) \]\n

for some scalars c_1 and c_2.

This means that any vector in the span must have its x-coordinate proportional to the first vector's x-coordinate (i.e., 1) and its y-coordinate proportional to the second vector's y-coordinate (i.e., 1).

Geometrically, this means that all vectors in the span lie on a line passing through the origin.

The answer is then the subspace of ℝ² consisting of all such vectors:

\[ \text{Span}(S) = \{(x, y) \in ℝ² : x = c_1, y = c_2\} \]
answerShort: The span is the set of all vectors (x, y) with x = 0 or y = 0." },

name: Span of a Set" },
statementHtml: Find the span of the set S = {(1, 2), (3, 4)} in R^2.
hints: Hint: Think about what vectors you can combine to get any vector in R^2.
solutionHtml:
To find the span, we need to determine which linear combinations of the given vectors produce all possible vectors in R^2. We can start by combining the two vectors:

  • \( (1, 2) + (-3, -4) = (-2, -2) \)
  • \( (1, 2) + (0, 2) = (1, 4) \)

This shows that we can combine the vectors to produce any vector in R^2. Therefore, the span of S is all of R^2.
